name.text: Open Research Conversation: Open Research with the Wellcome Trust

description.text: Join us for an online discussion of the Wellcome Trust's new Open Access policy, with Hannah Hope from the Wellcome Trust
description.html: Join us for an online discussion of the Wellcome Trust's new Open Access policy, with Hannah Hope from the Wellcome Trust

node.summary: Join us for an online discussion of the Wellcome Trust's new Open Access policy, with Hannah Hope from the Wellcome Trust

description.text:
UKRI is currently consulting on the future development of its open access policy, including the inclusion of monographs, edited collections and book chapters into the policy scope. The changes under consultation will affect all UKRI funded researchers. Particular areas that may be of interest are: funding for open access books, licensing requirements and embargo periods.
We invite researchers at all levels (including PGRs) to discuss the consultation, ask questions and provide feedback at an online forum. The feedback you provide will shape our institutional response to UKRI. 
The forum will be held via Blackboard Collaborate, and the link will be circulated to attendees prior to the event. The full consultation document can be found here, and it may be useful for you to read these frequently asked questions which are based on feedback we have already received. The forum will be structured around the issues raised in these FAQs, but we are happy to discuss any other questions or concerns you may have.
If you are unable to attend the forum, please leave your feedback here, or email fiona.chislett@sheffield.ac.uk.

We invite researchers at all levels (including PGRs) to discuss the consultation, ask questions and provide feedback at an online forum. The feedback you provide will shape our institutional response to UKRI. 

The forum will be held via Blackboard Collaborate, and the link will be circulated to attendees prior to the event. name.text: Our rights as authors and responsibilities as researchers

description.text:
"Our rights as authors and responsibilities as researchers"
This event will include talks from leading figures in the move towards responsible metrics and increasing authors' rights, as well as a panel discussion with contributions from across the University.
***Full details to follow***

description.text:
Is your data a bit messy?
Can't find that all-important file?
Looking for a better way to structure your data but not sure where to start?

Come along to this Bring Your Own Data workshop in Love Data Week and get hands-on support and advice to get your data in order. 
The session will start with some brief introductions to best practice in managing and analysing your data from experts in the Library and CiCS. We will then spend most of the time working with you to organise and structure your data - so make sure you bring some data with you!

name.text: Data Conversations: Delving into data visualisations

description.text:
Data Conversations are a chance for researchers and professional services staff to come together and discuss their research data and current issues in research data management. There will be presenters from across the University, as well as plenty of time to talk to colleagues and pizza to fuel our discussions.
Our first 'Data Conversation', to celebrate Love Data Week, will focus on the benefits and challenges of data visualisation for researchers.
Data visualisations allow research to be more easily explored, evaluated and understood than by looking at the raw data alone. Visualisations can help communicate research to new audiences, highlight trends during the early, exploratory stages of a research project, and make sense of big datasets.
Speakers will include:

Alasdair Rae (Urban Studies and Planning)
Colin Angus (SCHARR)
Charlotte Tomkins (History), Charles West (History), and Tom Stafford (Psychology)

The Library, CiCS and the Research Software Engineering team have recently begun to develop new services to support data visualisation and there will be a chance for researchers to feed back on what services they would like to see in the future.

There will be presenters from across the University, as well as plenty of time to talk to colleagues and pizza to fuel our discussions.

Our first 'Data Conversation', to celebrate Love Data Week, will focus on the benefits and challenges of data visualisation for researchers.

Data visualisations allow research to be more easily explored, evaluated and understood than by looking at the raw data alone. Visualisations can help communicate research to new audiences, highlight trends during the early, exploratory stages of a research project, and make sense of big datasets.

Speakers will include:

  • Alasdair Rae (Urban Studies and Planning)

  • Charlotte Tomkins (History), Charles West (History), and Tom Stafford (Psychology)

The Library, CiCS and the Research Software Engineering team have recently begun to develop new services to support data visualisation and there will be a chance for researchers to feed back on what services they would like to see in the future.

name.text: Open Access at The University of Sheffield (Wednesday)

description.text:
International Open Access Week is 20-26 October 2014.
Are you a researcher interested in submitting your publications to REF2020? Have you heard about the new HEFCE open access policy? Have you ever wondered what White Rose Research Online can do for you? If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then come along to this session on Wednesday 22nd October. Open Access Coordinator Carmen O'Dell will give a short presentation covering the basic concepts of open access, funder requirements, and the implications for researchers. There will also be lots of time available for discussion and questions, so please come along to find out what you need to do and how the Open Access team can help.
description.html:
International Open Access Week is 20-26 October 2014.

Are you a researcher interested in submitting your publications to REF2020? 

Have you heard about the new HEFCE open access policy? 

Have you ever wondered what White Rose Research Online can do for you? 

If the answer to any of these questions is yes, then come along to this session on Wednesday 22nd October. 

Open Access Coordinator Carmen O'Dell will give a short presentation covering the basic concepts of open access, funder requirements, and the implications for researchers. There will also be lots of time available for discussion and questions, so please come along to find out what you need to do and how the Open Access team can help.

frontmatter.title: Urban Observatories hackathon
frontmatter.description: The University of Sheffield hosted a three-day hackathon aimed to begin tackling the complex challenges involved in coordinating analytics using data from urban observatories across the UK.
